forumNotes.author: thewhitrbbit
forumNotes.content:
I was talking to my boss last week about the use of flash drives vs. CD's and trying to understand their objections to flash drives and one point that was brought up was the danger of a boot sector virus being spread via flash drive.  

Are there any strategies that can be employed to guard against this?

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Just to play devil's advocate ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) there is no problem in spreading a virus from a bootable or even non-bootable CD, with this regard I don't see the difference.  

I mean, you either prohibit the connection of ANY device to a PC or you are open to possible infections, the particular kind of media is pretty much irrelevant.  

A USB stick or hard disk may be MUCH "more dangerous" than a CD if we are talking of stealing info:  
[http://www.zimbio.co...Using USB Drive](http://www.zimbio.com/Windows+XP/articles/1557/Hack+Passwords+Using+USB+Drive "External link")  
[http://wiki.hak5.org...USB_Switchblade](http://wiki.hak5.org/wiki/USB_Switchblade "External link")  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: Adam_W
forumNotes.content:
If you mean the MBR of the OS being infected because it has been read of a USB flash drive that is no longer an issue. Windows NT does not allow you to modify your volume and disables direct access to your HDD and therefore you are safe from \*those type\* of viruses infecting your computer.  

However, being in a large organization where I work the main concerns with USB sticks usage is information risk... not just from the loss from theft because the data was not backed up.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> No joking , I thought mbr viruses were a thing of the past! > > [http://www.symantec....nder.win.nt.pdf](http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/reference/virus.behavior.under.win.nt.pdf "External link") > [http://technet.micro...y/cc977223.aspx](http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc977223.aspx "External link") > > "Windows 2000 is immune to viruses infecting these disk structures during normal operation, because it only accesses physical disks through protected mode disk drivers" Yep, though "normal operation" does not apply to "virus operation". ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Play a bit with the dsfok toolkit: [http://www.ozemail.c...eezip/freeware/](http://www.ozemail.com.au/~nulifetv/freezip/freeware/ "External link") or with MBRWIX, MBRFIX and the like. It should be impossible to write to the MBR, right? If you read attentively (and between the lines) the .pdf you linked to: > **MBR Infection by Booting Off an Infected Floppy Diskette** > The Windows NT operating system is still susceptible to this type of infection. Since NT does not have control of > the computer during system boot-up, booting from an infected floppy diskette allows the virus to infect the MBR of > any of the physical drives on the system using the usual techniques. This vector of infection is quite common, and > we can expect to see more of the same. > > **MBR Infection by Running a Dropper Program or Multipartite Virus** > Dropper programs and multipartite viruses infect the MBR of the hard drive by using BIOS or DOS services to write > directly to the hard drive. Since Windows NT prevents all such writes from within Windows NT DOS box, this type > of infection will be completely prevented while NT is running. However, if the computer in question also has the > ability to boot to DOS or Windows 95, then the user could boot to one of these operating systems and execute the > dropper program or multipartite virus normally.
First case is EXACTLY what a USB stick can cause (if you boot from it). Second case states (correctly) that you cannot anymore write to MBR using BIOS or DOS services, .... but you can use Windows NT ones allright....![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Operating systems evolve, virii do the same...![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) jaclaz
